files.name: 1885 transcripts.txt
files.content:
Letter to Alice Austen from F.E. Langford 1885 April 25

18 Townsend Ave Clifton

25th Apl ‘85

Dear Miss Austin [sic]

Mr Bruce & I are going to have a few friends on Wednesday next to spend
the evening & would be very pleased to have the pleasure of your company
Sincerely yours F.E. Langford

Letter to Alice Austen from Alice Cornell Austen 1885 June 12

Friday, June 12th

My dearest Babe

I was so glad to get the Telegram. We are all right here, your Grandma
is much better, eats [missing one or two words] deal, and sees every
o[ne who?] comes. Uncle Dave a[nd Aunt?] Meaghe[r?] have been [missing
one or two words] Louis Tribus sent the enclosed last might, do as you
like about going to it, I suppose you would want some girl to go with
you. The dogs [missing one or two words] and stay in long [missing one
or two words] great deal. I saw Julia [missing one or two words] on the
road the [illegible word]

Give my love to all Your Mamma

Letter to Alice Austen from Alice Austen Cornell 1885 June 17

Staten Island

June 17th

My dearest Child— How have you got through a whole week, the heat came
as you said it would. Yesterday it was very hot here, but today it is
cool and damp. Miss Bennett came on Tuesday, so we are very busy. She
said she saw some of the boys on the car coming from the New Brighton
Cricket grounds one day last week, they had their rackets, one of the
Wright boys had his head all bandaged up, covering his right eye,
forehead, and nose, he must have got hit pretty hard. Your Grandma is
doing very well, the nurse says between two and three oclock [sic] in
the morning she has a little attack of shortness of breathing, so that
she sits up for a while. Otherwise she gets through the night very well.
Edith [McReeves?] and her mother were here on Friday Edith was very
sorry not to see you, she is not exactly pretty, but is ladylike and
very pleasant. She is much thinner than she used to be. Mrs Benham and
her niece were here yesterday Mrs B. is a forlorn looking woman, a great
talker. I have not seen any of the girls, I think they know you are
away. I meant you to take the pink fan with gold sticks to wear with the
pink sateen, I hope your dresses were not very badly creased. To day and
night you will be pretty busy, if you wear your white dress to the
reception, you could put on the cream colored sash, & wear the frosted
[illegible word] for the neck caught with the crescent I suppose you got
your Auntie’s silver pin. I met her on the street as she had just bought
it. The dogs are all right. Ralph Munroe has been photographing the
house. good bye my precious

Love to Pete & Nellie. Your Mamma

Letter to Alice Austen from Gertrude Eccleston 1885 June 22

St. John’s Rectory

June 22nd

My dear Alice,

It was very nice of you to write me when you are so busy having a good
time, I speak from experience as you know. I hope you will get this
scrawl before you leave for home as I have not delayed in answering. Of
course you are anxious to hear how we are coming on with the May pole, I
really think they have improved a little in some ways but Alice it is
the most discouraging thing we have ever undertaken We have never had a
full rehearsal yet, last time three boys were missing, I think that if
we had to practice much monger we would not have any boys, as they are
getting tired and disgusted as well as the committee and I don’t blame
them one bit, it is such hot weather. We have the stage all up and all
the dresses are made, I must say they are not very beautiful, I think
they are too long, but I guess they will do, we are going to make the
children sing it is so much better it drowns the noise they make a
little. Those that knew the step in the beginning have forgotten it or
so it seems, so we just let them hop any way they want to. We have had
one rehearsal on the stage and we have another this aft & one Tuesday
eve of every thing, [Birtwistle?] is coming to play for us and I expect
it will go much better when he plays. We have the old May pole form the
German Club rooms, with a wheel on the top, so the string don’t get
mixed up any more which is one blessing, as you can judge from the tenor
of my letter, I am not very enthusiastic over it, but everyone seems to
think it will be all right, anyway it will please the [ordianse?
possibly misspelling of audience] we expect will be here. The children
have sold $70.00 worth of tickets themselves, is’ent that splendid, and
they are still selling some, it is splendid the interest they are taking
in it I think we will easily make $100.00. We have all found Florence
Hodges very hard to work with she has so much to say for herself and she
must have the curtain this way & the stage that way so that we are about
wild, I believe it is all settled amicably at last, but for how long
“land knows.” Will you be home in time for the circus? I have been away
on a visit for a few day[s] at Ridgewood N.J. at the Palmers and have
had a splendid time, brought Gertrude back with me for over Sunday, she
has just gone home. You haven’t missed any thing down here as far as I
can find out except that play at the Club rooms “Caste”, which I hear
was a great success, I was away & did not go but Howard has told me all
about it, Mrs De Kay looked magnificently & so did Miss Vyse, the oldest
Mr Walker was the poorest actor and Miss Williams did not do well as she
had a part that did not suit her at all a lively saucy kind of a part.
Then there has been a fair at the Presbyterian church where I should
imagine they raised Cain from all I hear from the Butlers. Miss Bechtel
was there in full glory behind the flower table. Now Alice I might keep
on for ever in this strain but I am smoking hot and awfully hungry. You
must be having an awfully jolly time and you will have to tell me all
when you get home, I miss you dreadfully so do come home soon.

Lots of love Your friend Trudie Eccleston

Letter to Alice Austen from Alice Austen Cornell 1885 June 28

Staten Island Sunday [Missing one or more words] a long time—my
[deares?]t Child since I saw [you?] and we all say the [house? or
place?] is dreadfully quiet, bu[t y]ou are quite right to stay where you
are having a pleasant time. I hear nothing about the neighbourhood, but
it must be very quiet. [Lou Batsis?] was married a week ago Saturday,
and went up in the 4. boat, there was no announcement in the papers, and
I suppose no r[eceptio]n. I do not see why they kept it so quiet. They
go to housekeeping at [missing one or more words] Ernst is better, he
[has or had] [missing one or more words] trouble with his lung[s?]
[missing one or more words] this from Miss Bennett [missing one or more
words] made me two visits [missing one or more words] in all. We have
[missing one or more words] making the brown [missing one or more words]
the blue sateen, and [missing one or more words] the red [cakes?]. She
will come again week after next. You poor child, how do you get on with
so few underclothes and that white dress, what a bother. I told Miss B.
about it, she will try to alter it. The Boat House boys invited the
girls of the Fair tables to a Barge party to [Petelers?], I saw them
pass the [missing one or more words] Th[ursda]y evening, I believe it
was. [Missing word] Smith asked your [missing one or more words] on the
boat Saturday [missing one or more words] if you were home yet. [The?]
Sunday school exhibition [missing one or more words] crowded, many could
[missing one or more words] in, Claire and her [missing one or more
words] stood outside. The [missing one or more words] very well, to day
was so damp and foggy that I lit my fire to dry the room, [illegible
name, possibly a dog or cat?] found it out and slept for hours on the
rug Your Grandma is doing very well, to day she came in to dinner, and
helped the soup as usual. She is having her leg dressed with ‘Idiophone’
which has a dreadful chemical smell, [two illegible words] upstairs into
your Auntie’s room. One of the cisterns is out, the one [missing one or
more words] kitchen, and the oth[er?] [missing one or more words] so
badly that I use [missing one or more words] water. Take care of
[yourself?] dear Child, do not [missing one or more words] too hard, you
will [missing one or more words] want a new tennis dre[ss?] [missing one
or more words] money enough for the [missing one or more words]. I
suppose Nellie will be coming to the Island before long, give my love to
her. Ralph’s new photos of the house are very pretty indeed he thought
your scroll work cross was very well done, and he is a good judge. Good
bye, my dearest I wish I could hear your little whistle Your
affectionate [Mam]a

Letter to Alice Austen from Elisabeth B. Strong and Eva M. Hartnell 1885
July 6^(th)

My dear Alice:

I’ve no doubt but that you will open your eyes when you receive this
note; it is a sort of partnership affair, both of us writing at the same
time So please excuse penmanship (Eva has a better word but mine must
answer.) You will come and go over to Helen’s with us at six o’clock
won’t you? Wear just what you please, as I expect to. I do hope there
will be no more rain. Hoping to see you later, I am Aff’ly yours
Elisabeth B. Strong July 6th/’85

Monday

My dear Alice, Bess does not want me to write, but I must say that I
hope you will come up and go over with us. We are both writing at the
same time and as I have very much the worst position you must excuse
chirography. Isn’t that good? I searched the Dictionary for it. Wear
your oldest clothes for it will probably rain again, but do come what
ever you do. Have you recovered from Saturday’s spree? I have not as you
may see. Rhyme!! Don’t think that I am quite daft It is only one of the
eccentricities of genius. Most lovingly Eva M.H.

Letter to Alice Austen from Elisabeth B. Strong 1885 July 19

New Brunswick July 19th /’85

My dear Alice:-- Perhaps when you discover that this letter was written
on Sunday you will hesitate about reading it; New Brunswickers are never
troubled with such compunctions, but with Staten Island people it may be
different. You began your letter with a slurring remark about our
“metropolis” or rather our weather, which was unjust, and words cannot
describe the pain it caused me. However, I will try to forget and
forgive. Have you heard the song “Forget, Forgive” by the same Composer
as “Some Day”? Eva is a little crazy over it, and I have to sing it to
her frequently in order to keep her quiet. Saturday morning after
leaving you we went down town, and I invested in several songs;
“Dreaming,” “The Romany Bass,” “By the Blue Sea,” and “Welcome Pretty
Primrose” They are all pretty, but the two first I am specially gone
over, or rather the first two. Thank you very much for your account of
the wedding; it must have been a very pretty sight, and I am wishing
that some one of my friends would get married and have a military
wedding. By the way my dear, I did not know that you were open to
congratulations, why did you not confide in me? We told Mr. Beebe’s
fortune here on Friday evening and we found that he was to marry you. I
believe I am to be his second, so you had better not come hear me or I
may administer cold poison. He wished me to tell you that his moustache
is getting on nicely. He has been trying to get up a party to go down
and call upon you, but I do not think there are many who can go. It
would be real fun, and a very pleasant trip, but do not expect us until
you see us. You may see Harry Beebe before long, for when a young
gentleman gets to that point where he wants the postage stamp from a
young lady’s letter, the next thing will be his calling on her quite
often, even though she may live at some distance. Eva’s father came last
Tuesday morning and expected to start for home with his “little
daughter,” next Thursday They are going by steamers to Old Point
Comfort, and are very anxious that some of us should accompany them that
far, but there is very little prospect of it. We have not been to
“tennis” in the morning very much since you left. Our second match game
came off last Tuesday evening, but not even the prospect of being
treated to cream by the other side could make us win, and we were beaten
6-1, 6-4. We have found some very pleasant acquaintances in the
Baldwins, a family from New York who live above us. They have been made
honorary members of the tennis club, and come down quite frequently in
the evenings. To-morrow morning we hope to be able to do some playing,
but the last two or three days have been so dreadfully warm, that even I
was daunted. You should have been here the other evening when we had our
musicale. Mr. Ludlow with his flute, Mr. Beebe with his violin and your
little friend with her piano. We practiced for an hour or more, and then
Charlie Ludlow gave us a performance on his accordion. We had jugs,
waltzes, classical music, and a lansier danced by four the musician
included. I do not know what is the matter, but I am leaving letters out
of my words in a remarkable way. Eva sends “lots of love” and will write
very soon; she has a message for you. I had not intended to write such a
lengthy epistle but I trust you will be able to get through it. You must
send me just as long an one in return. You had my address correctly
except that you ought put [sic] Care Woodbridge Strong. Write soon
again, and believe me Very aff’ly yours Elisabeth B. Strong. P.S. How is
Mr. Ogilby? I ask for Eva’s sake you know.

Letter to Alice Austen from Eva M Hartnell 1885 July 20

care M.G. [Murray?] #707 Lucas Place Louisville Ky.

New Brunswick N.J. July 20th /85.

My dear Alice: I think you were very unkind not to write to me too, but
I will forgive you on condition that you answer this epistle soon, and
at length. We miss you, dreadfully. Life has not been the same to
several young men since you left. Neither have we had anything in the
way of gaiety since your departure. All joy went with you. Isn’t that
melting? Do you know I think it is a great shame I am not a man, I could
make love beautifully. But a truce to all this nonsense. I suppose Bess
told you in her letter yesterday that Papa has come for me and that we
expect to leave Thursday for Louisville. I want to get home dreadfully,
but I am not at all anxious to leave N.B. I don’t want to tell
everything that Bess did, so I will say nothing about the Baldwins
except that they are quite agreeable, and I am only afraid Miss Blanche
will prove a rival. We had an engagement with them and C.B.L. at half
past seven for Tennis this morning. We go there at nine to find the
grounds deserted. Were’nt [sic] we mad? Well Sone!! Have you seen Mr
Robert Ogilby lately? I read the cricket news with the greatest interest
now. I never cared anything for the game before, but I begin to think it
must be very enjoyable. You may not believe it but I have improved in
Tennis to such an extent, that I am to play in singles against Fred
Deshler to-night. My Guardian was up to call Friday and he told me to
give you a heart full of love for him. He said that his trip to the
Island (with you) would ever be a bright spot in his life and that he
would never be able to think of it without a thrill of rapture. Poor
fellow, he has been way down down since you left. I really hate to go
away and leave him in such a condition. Be kind to him, I pray you for
my sake at least. Those are not the exact words that he used, but it was
what he meant I am sure. I intended to write you a sensible letter and
try to counteract the impression that you must have of me, but the
impishness is in me and must come out. I will wait until I see you to
finish that story. It is too long to write. Do write soon. I think I
gave you my Louisville address—but I will repeat it. Bess sends love.
With a great deal from Your very sincere friend Eva M. [Hartnell or
Hartwell]

Bessie Hill

[Nettie or Hettie] Hill

Bessie Strong

Eva [Hartwell or Hartnell]

Emily Neilson

Annie Ogilby

Alice Austen

Mrs P.T. Austen.

-----------------------------

Charlie Deshler

Fred Deshler

Harry Beebe

Charlie Ludlow

Tony Neilson [Thirston?] Challen

Bob Ogilby

Dorie Strong

Dr. P.T. Austen

Letter to Alice Austen from Eva M Hartnell 1885 August 8

Louisville, Ky.

Aug 8th 1885.

My dearest Alice;

Your delightful letter came Thursday, just when I was beginning to think
I must have said something in my letter to offend you, and that you were
going to give me the “cut direct”. My spirits went up several degrees on
the receipt of that letter, (I have been down in the depths since I left
the East). Oh my! how jolly you are!!! I do wish I were hear enough to
have a chat with you, for I can not say all I should like on paper. We
had a delightful trip home. The sea voyage was simply lovely. As we
passed the Island I thought of you and blew you a kiss. Did you get it?
I was not at all sea sick much to my delight, for I was teased mightily
before I left N.B. and was told that there was no chance for me. The day
we left N.B., by the time I got to New York I was almost in tears. Papa
was really worried I was so glum and disagreeable. (So different
[illegible mark] from the way I usually am!). We had a number of things
to attend to and then went to have lunch. Just as we came out of
Delmonico’s who should we meet but Fred [Deshler?] Dear me! I was so
glad to see him! He walked to the elevated station with us, so that he
was the last friend I saw. It is delightful to be at home again after
having been away for over a year, There have been a great many changes.
It seems to me that every one I know is married or dead or something. I
have been very quiet as yet, and have only had a few callers, but next
week I anticipate a gay time. I think I may possibly go to Indianapolis
for a short visit, and if I do I will have no end of fun, as it is the
loveliest place to visit I was ever in. Every one does so much to
entertain you. I had a very cordial [illegible word] from Douglas
Shirley (the Author of the Inner Sisterhood you know) the other day. I
saw a splendid burlesque on his latest book the other day, and if I can
get a copy I will send it to you. He sued the man who published it, so I
may not be able to get one, but I shall try. Douglas is such a case! I
hope he will call soon, so I can have some fun. My dear have you not
some sort of a picture of yourself that you can send me? Even a tintype
would be very thankfully received. Can’t you and Mr Robert Ogilby have
one taken together? He in his cricket suit and you in your tennis
costume. I think you had better, but at any rate, send me some sort of a
photo of yourself. I want it for my rogue’s gallery. (That is to pay you
back for saying I would not care whether there were chaperones or not).
I certainly did not tell my brother about any resemblance in the picture
and I no longer carry it in my pocket book. What do you think of that? I
am glad you congratulated Bess, for it shows me that you had no designs
on “her False love” for my dear you have captured my Guardian’s heart,
and no mistake. I was not the only one who noticed it. My dear my
message was better than yours after all, for a large part of mine was
true, while yours was all made up. How I laughed over that letter! I
read it about six times. And now for a sweet message for “Bob”. What
shall I say? That he is my own true love? I can’t, for that’s not true.
That if he trys [sic] he may some day be my own true love? I can’t, for
there is not the slightest possibility of such a think. That I send my
kindest regards and hope he may win you for his true love? Yes, I think
that will do very nicely. I do hope I shall see you in New York next
winter. I will not be at #33 Lex Ave as I have changed my boarding
place, but I will keep you posted as to where I will be. I am living on
peaches and watermelon. Does not that sound choleric for you? If you can
wade through this dreary epistle you will do well. I should advise you
to take it a little at a time. Don’t wait so long to answer this please,
and do send the photo. I will be at #707 Lucas Place until the last of
September. With oceans of love, As ever your friend Eva M. Hartnell

Saturday.

#707 Lucase Place

Lousiville Ky.

c/o N.G. [illegible name beginning with M].

Letter to Alice Austen from Julia Bredt 1885 August 8

Aug. 8th 185 west Bethlehem Dearest Alice, I was so glad to hear from
you. I have written two or three times and have not had any answer so I
guess you have not received them (my letters) in one of them I sent the
tin types of the children & one of myself. It is funny But never mind, I
will send them again when they have them taken. The children are getting
up an entertainment and they are in this room talking away at a fine
rate so you must excuse mistakes. All the children have been away Carl
is away now it seemed so funny without them. I have had [company?] all
Summer & have not been away at all I play Tennis a great deal & I like
it ever so much, we have a very pretty set & we play on a very lovely
court so altogether it is very nice. I do not know if I shall go away
this summer if I do I am going in a week or so I most likely will come &
stay a day or so with Emily, & so will be almost sure to see you if I am
not on the Island I will try & come over & see you from [illegible word]
I am if it is not [illegible word]. I do not feel like beginning school
again at all the summer has passed so quickly—[Lella?] is staying with
me now & she told me all about the wedding also her sister who is
ingaged [sic] [to?] Lieutenant Allen went [to?] it & she said it was
lovely I had a letter from Emily yesterday and she said that you had
been playing Tennis at E. Wrights, do you still like it as much as ever?
We had a very nice time last evening, went to play Tennis in the first
of the evening and then Mr. Boothe played the Guitar & he sang it
sounded very pretty. I must say good bye now I do hope you will write
very soon [In?] care [of?] if I do go away I will go in a week or so,
[illegible word] Mama’s & my love to your grandmama--& all the children
send love I am your loving friend Julia Frederika Bredt

Letter to Alice Austen from Elisabeth B. Strong 1885 August 12

Littleton, Mass.

August 12th /’85

My dear Alice:-- To say that I was very glad to receive your letter
would be putting it mildly; but you were so long about answering my
lengthy epistle, that I was worried and feared it might have proved too
much for your feeble constitution. Another idea that occurred to me was,
that you might have eloped with one of those cavalry officers I know
that you were much impressed by them, and as you are naturally rather
susceptible, I thought your better judgment might have given way to the
impulse of the moment. I was on the point of interviewing your Aunt,
when the long-looked-for letter made its appearance. It was followed a
day or two later by your note urging us to come to Staten Island, but
after the threat you implied for some harmless remark I had made, it
would not be safe for me to be in your neighborhood. It is very kind of
you to want to see us, but just now we (“the crowd”) are “scattered to
the four winds”. Etta Macaulay is at Martha’s Vineyard; Charlie Ludlow
at Ocean Beach, the Desher boys were there for last Sunday also I
believe; Harry Beebe is at Saratoga; the Hills, I suppose, are in New
Brunswick though I do not know, and [Doni?] and I are in Mass., as you
have perceived doubtless. We were not really in earnest when we spoke of
making a descent upon you, for I do not think we could get up a partly
much as we should enjoy it. One of these days, however, when I invade
“the Island” (not Blackwell’s) you will see enough of me. We left home
last Friday at noon, and after a most tedious journey, arrived here at
noon the next day. The only amusement I had after leaving home, was in
watching the urchins dive off the wharf at Hew York. They did not
trouble themselves to take off any clothes, except in one instance, when
the boy did not take the trouble to put any on. Then I was interested in
something the other side of the boat. But most of them jumped in just as
they came from the streets, and if one of them objected to a bath, his
companions would pick him up and drop him overboard. Really it was very
amusing. You may wonder where Littleton is, and what sort of a place it
is. Well, it is about thirty miles from Boston on the Fitchburg road,
and did, last May, boast a population of nine hundred and ninety-four.
But some of the inhabitants have since died, and as there has not been a
corresponding number of births, I suppose they are further from a
thousand than before. The scenery and the drives about the neighborhood
are beautiful, but I never walk much while here. I range between the
houses of an Uncle and an Aunt, and know comparatively few people beside
my relatives. My days are passed in driving, reading, working, eating,
playing with the children, and making myself generally agreeable(?) and
last, but most emphatically not least, sleeping. There are four
generations in this house; the oldest an old lady of ninety-one and the
youngest a young lady of five months. As you may imagine there is
nothing wildly exciting about this life, but I thoroughly enjoy it
nevertheless. Next week, I believe there is to be a Sunday-school
“picnic” and then my bliss will be complete. But of all things I should
like to be here in the winter and attend a “Boxborough ball”. Boxborough
is a village about [from, possibly mistake for four or five?] miles from
us, and I was told last evening that at these balls, the gentlemen are
in the habit of dancing in their stocking-feet and sometimes in their
shirt-sleeves. Imagine it! Wouldn’t you like to see one? If you have
seen the play “Joshua Whitcomb” you have seen a very good representation
of the way in which such things are managed in these rural districts.
Aunt Lucy has promised to invite me here next winter for one of the
“select parties” in the town-hall, which she says are very funny. I had
a long letter from Eva on Monday, in which she complained of not having
heard from you. But hers was sent last Wednesday (5th) before she would
have had time to receive yours. So you think Eva and I “conspired
together” before writing you? No my dear, and I did not see anything
mysterious about my letter; I cannot speak of hers. You ask about the
Baldwins. We have found them very pleasant, but just now like other
people, they are not “in town”. I knew Mr. Martin was coming to visit
“Harry” as you irreverently call him but did not see either of them
while he was in New Brunswick. Mr. H. Baldwin spend Sunday at Staten
Island two or three weeks ago. Is not Mr. Martin a brother of your
particular friend? We have been invited up to the Baldwins’ two or three
times, to play tennis and spend the evening, and we like them all very
much. I only wish they could be persuaded to spend the winter at our
metropolis. You invited me to write a longer letter “next time” and tho’
I did not intend to spin it out so, it has lengthened itself out without
my realizing it. Be a good girl and write me soon, and suppose you try
ten pages “next time”. I do not know how ling I shall be here, but
probably for two weeks at any rate. Do not become venturesome and get
drowned diving off that dock. Charlie Ludlow said when I wrote you again
to send his regards, and say he hoped we should see you in New Brunswick
before long. “So say we all of us”.

Most aff’ly yours Elizabeth B.S

My address— Care Col. J.A. Harwood Littleton Mass.

Letter to Alice Austen from Gertrude Eccleston 1888 August 27

Viault House

Lake Mahopac

Aug. 27^(th)

My dear Alice; Your prompt letter calls for a speedy reply so here goes.
I think the pictures you sent me to look at splendid, of course they are
a little faded, but I am sure the success of that lense [sic] is beyond
doubt and am glad you own it. Mr Manner saw the tennis groupe [sic] and
wanted me to ask you if you could allow him to pay for one he thought it
so good of himself & the others. Do as you like about it but I think you
need not pay any attention to it. The Collins think the pictures
splendid and they each want one of the groupe. Have you got your camera
with you now? Mr B. is still here, he will spend another week here as it
agrees with him so well, he has gained three pounds already I remain the
same. Nellie Lord was up here for a week & Jack and George Betts came up
for Sunday. There was a large ball at the Thompson House Saturday night,
we all went over in full dress costumes. The big dining room was all
fixed up and they threw different colored lights on the dancers which
made a lovely effect, the red light was immensely becoming but the green
& blue were gastly [sic], they call it [fantom?] dancing. There were
crows of people there and I almost danced myself sick as I was not
really fit to dance a step. We had a great time watching that Miss
Michael she had a fight with her lover and gave all her dances to
another man she has treated him horribly it is the talk of the hotel, I
would give a good deal to know what the trouble is. The tennis court it
[sic] swarming with men from morning until night and unless I walk over
with my racket (which by the way is a perfect beauty) & a partner to
hold me up I never get a chance to play at all. Fortunately they do not
use my net any more. Harry Wright wrote me such a smart letter enclosing
a [illegible word] of original poetry about my defeat. I wrote back in
my truest style thanking him for the racket. He got me a rough handle
because the other kind are only made to order and in quantities. I can
play finely with it and hope to be able to win something “some day”. I
had a letter from Jule and she is playing in a tournament at Ridgefield
or where ever she is, she had great times with [Konrad?] & Pussie;
paddling and fishing. I miss you very much indeed my dear ad feel quite
lonely in my huge room. The Collins go to [Rize?] this Friday and we
leave here in the 7th. The people are beginning to go away & I say good
riddance to bad rubbish. Now then farewell and write soon. The family &
friends in general wish to be remembered to you. With Love, ever your
friend Trudie.

Letter to Alice Austen from Grace Hustace Simonson, 1885 August 28

2020 Fifth Ave. N.Y.

Aug 28th 1885

My dear Alice,

I meant [to have answered] your letter before [this, but] you know how
easy [it is to] put it off from [time to time?] especially when you
[have] nothing particular to write. I was down on the Island when at the
Brittons when your letter reached me. I made quite a long visit there;
and tried to go down and see you, but it was during the hottest weather
and when the mosquitoes were [at] the thickest, so that [cousin?]
Harriet did not like [us to drive] the horse so far. [I expected?] to
have made [a visit at?] my Aunt’s but [find that] it is not likely [I
shall] be able to go there. [At any rate?] if my seeing you depends on
going there it is highly probable I shall not see you this summer. So I
want you to come up and spend the day with me very soon. Next week I am
going away for a few days but after that any time would be perfectly
convenient for me. You can send me a card the day before if you like.
[If any?] of the girls will come with you I should like very much to
have them. [Please come?] you never have yet. [It is so?] long ago since
I [wrote?] you that I have most [forgotten] what has happened since. I
worked hard at Cooper all winter and was all tired out by summer. I am
just beginning to feel myself again. Did you know that I took one of the
first prizes in the school? It rather repaid me for working so hard. I
suppose I shall go back [in] October but not to study [so hard?]. I am
taking [lessons in] china painting and like it ever so much though have
not done much yet. [Do or So?] you play tennis as much as ever. [T]his
cool weather is just the thing for it. We have to be contented here with
croquet. They allow us to play on the lawns in [Mt.?] Morris park and we
enjoy it so much. Wednesday I had a splendid game with a young gentleman
friend and today I played with [my cousin?] Sophie is pretty [well?] but
she has been [illegible]able, and at one [time we?] were very much
[bothered?] about her. I guess [her party?] will not be very soon. I
have not thought of my [illegible word] dress yet. I shall have to
finish now as I am so sleepy; it is pretty late and we have had such
lots of company this week that I am all tired out. Please give my love
to your Mamma [and?] Grandma and with much for yourself I remain your
loving friend Grace

Letter to Alice Austen from Julia Bredt 1885 August 8

Aug. 8th

185 west Bethlehem

Dearest Alice,

I was so glad to hear from you. I have written two or three times and
have not had any answer so I guess you have not received them (my
letters) in one of them I sent the tin types of the children & one of
myself. It is funny But never mind, I will send them again when they
have them taken. The children are getting up an entertainment and they
are in this room talking away at a fine rate so you must excuse
mistakes. All the children have been away Carl is away now it seemed so
funny without them. I have had [company?] all Summer & have not been
away at all I play Tennis a great deal & I like it ever so much, we have
a very pretty set & we play on a very lovely court so altogether it is
very nice. I do not know if I shall go away this summer if I do I am
going in a week or so I most likely will come & stay a day or so with
Emily, & so will be almost sure to see you if I am not on the Island I
will try & come over & see you from [illegible word] I am if it is not
[illegible word]. I do not feel like beginning school again at all the
summer has passed so quickly—[Lella?] is staying with me now & she told
me all about the wedding also her sister who is ingaged [sic] [to?]
Lieutenant Allen went [to?] it & she said it was lovely I had a letter
from Emily yesterday and she said that you had been playing Tennis at E.
Wrights, do you still like it as much as ever? We had a very nice time
last evening, went to play Tennis in the first of the evening and then
Mr. Boothe played the Guitar & he sang it sounded very pretty. I must
say good bye now I do hope you will write very soon [In?] care [of?] if
I do go away I will go in a week or so, [illegible word] Mama’s & my
love to your grandmama--& all the children send love I am your loving
friend Julia Frederika Bredt

Letter to Alice Austen from Elisabeth B. Strong 1885 October 7

New Brunswick Oct. 7th/’85 My dear Alice: I purposely waited until after
your tennis tournament should be over before writing to you, hoping that
you would afford me an opportunity for congratulating you on a glorious
victory. I have been searching the paper each morning for news of you
and was highly delighted when I saw you had beaten two of your
opponents. But yesterday news was not what I wanted to see, and now it
is my painful duty to condole with you. Your name has been appearing in
print a great deal lately my dear; so far I have heard nothing very
dreadful, of you however. Cousin Evie sent me one of the Staten Island
papers containing an account of the “Cricketers’ Ball;” from it I
learned that “Miss Austen was attired in White nun’s veiling, profusely
trimmed with lace, a pearl necklace and pearls on her hair.” Did you
have a good time? Mr. Baldwin told me he went with your party, and was
dancing with Miss Eccleston when she sprained her ankle. It must have
somewhat spoiled the fun for all of you. I would have given a great deal
to have stayed for the Ball; Cousin Evie urged me very much to do so and
held out all sorts of inducements for a longer visit. If I had had a
party-dress with me I don’t believe I could have withstood the
temptation. However we had a most delightful time at the phantom party
at Mrs. [Wells’?] the same evening, and the Thursday evening following
we all met again at a “Progressive Euchre” party at the Deshlers’. Of
course I took no prize; it is against my principles to do such a thing.
Our last gaiety was a “dove” or “hen” tea-party given by Mrs. Dr. Rice.
It was very small, only about fourteen girls being invited but we had a
very pleasant time. I have been indulging in a new sort of work lately
which could hardly be called “fancy-work,” at any rate I do not fancy
it! Isn’t that most atrocious, but I beg any number of pardons and won’t
do so any more! The work referred to is housework and O, how, I detest
it! We have been without servants for more than a week, and though we
have a waitress coming (?) next Wednesday still we have as yet engaged
no cook. New Brunswick is particularly destitute of that article of
furniture just now, and I cannot get Mother to try in New York. However
I hope “better times are coming,” and that we shall be settled one of
these days. Have just received a letter from Eva; she is very much
pleased with her hew home and her school, and everything in fact. Her
new address is 105 West 40th; care Mrs. S. J. Seymour, but probably she
has already sent it to you. Have you developed that plate yet? But I
imagine that the tournament has not allowed you much time or thought for
anything else. I am waiting patiently for that picture of yourself you
promised me. Doesn’t the proverb run “Patient waiters are no losers”?
Let us hope it will be proved correct in this case. How is the
Englishman who [illegible word] the camera or rather two cameras; does
he come over three times a day as usual? You should have been at church
last Sunday evening; our choir rose in numbers to sixteen, and the
behavior was what might have been expected. Without doubt Dr. Woodbridge
is one of the most patient in existence. I hope you will not form a very
bad opinion of me for sending such a looking letter, but my ink and pen
are both on a strike and I am too lazy to hunt up better. Please
remember me to your mother and to Mrs. Miller, also to Miss Wright when
you see her. I have as yet had no time to pursue my study of chiromancy
but hope to do so “some-day.” With much love to yourself, and hoping
soon to hear from you I am Aff’ly yours Elisabeth Briard Strong.

Letter to Alice Austen from E Bruce 1885 November 2

57 Broadway 2 Novr 1885 Dear Miss Austin [sic]/ Our straw-ride of last
Thursday has been turned into a dance at the boat house for next
Thurs-day –5th inst. Please come and have a jolly time. Mrs MacDonald
and others will matronize the party. We will meet about eight o’clock,
Yours sincerely [illegible name beginning with E] Bruce

Letter to Alice Austen from Grace Hustace Simonson, 1885 November 3

2020 Fifth Ave N.Y.

Nov. 3rd 185 [sic]

Dear Alice

Don’t we keep up a rushing correspondence, actually I am ashamed of you.
Now I have had some excuse; doing a great deal of everything and not
much in particular since I saw you last. But seriously when are you
coming up. The weather Will not be any pleasanter later, can’t you come
sometime next week, that will give you plenty of time to get ready. Last
week we were all busy at a fair for the benefit of our church. It was an
extremely pretty one though I believe not financially successful. The
ladies in charge of different tables chose the holidays in the year and
dressed their tables to represent them Christmas day was a lovely little
cottage covered with snow (cotton) and greens. Washington’s birthday a
tent. April day an immense umbrella of white and pink mull and glass
bead [sic] sewed on for rain. May day a large may pole with the colored
net caught to different parts of the table. Thanksgiving day the
prettiest of all, a thatched cottage with husked corn, pumpkins and fall
fruits and flowers brought in as decorations. I took a dreadful cold the
last day and have not been out of the house since but getting better
fast. I am not going back to Cooper for the present, I may after
Christmas but possibly not until next year. I want to try and get over
my colds first. But I have my china painting and once can always find
plenty to do here. What are you thinking of doing this winter? Though it
is not much use to plan is it? Please let us hear from you soon, and let
it be favorably, give my love to all the friends and with much for
yourself. I remain Sincerely yours Grace

Letter to Alice Austen from Elisabeth B. Strong 1885 November 7

New Brunswick.

Nov. 7th/’85

My dear Alice:

-- I’ve only been waiting to see what gaiety was in the wind before
sending for [one or two missing words, possibly you] to come and m[one
or two missing words, possibly make me] a visit. My pat[one or two
missing words] met with its re[one or two missing words] the 4th of
December there is to be a “calico-ball” and we are anticipating any
amount of fun. It is not yet decided where it will be held but probably
in the “assembly room.” Now my dear, I want you to say that you will
come over and be here for New Brunswick’s great event. Give me as long a
visit as you can—and only let me know what day and hour to expect you
and I will meet you [one or two missing words, probably at the] depot. I
do not know exactly [one or two missing words, probably what] sort of
costumes [one or two missing words] allowable at th[e ball?] but
something in the fancy-dress line I presume, and of course they must be
of “calico.” In this case, that term may be stretched to mean almost
everything that is not silk, velvet, or woolen. Do not get up anything
elaborate or you will outshine me. We certainly are going back to
summer; the heat is really oppressive. I am hoping that it will clear
off to-day so that we shall have a pleasant evening for the organ
recital at the Second Reformed Church. Of course you have heard through
your [one or two missing words] the new organ that has been [one or two
missing words] there; I hear Prof. Austen is to pla[… one or two missing
words or partial words, first word possibly play …]he performer this
evening wi[th? one or two missing words] Clarence Eddy and we expect a
great treat. Next Wednesday there is to be a Progressive Euchre party at
Miss Bessie Palmer’s. I do not think you met her last summer did you?
Last [one or two missing words] was a small [one or two missing words]
at Dr. Scott’s [one or two missing words]or [for?] his sister, but [one
or two missing words] not go because [one or two missing words]adache
[headache?] but heard it was a very pleasant affair. But I must not
write more now. O, I am so stupid and sleepy this morning; please excuse
all deficiencies. Had a letter from Eva yesterday; has she written you
lately? Hoping soon to hear from you—I am with much love Yours aff’ly
Elisabeth B. Strong

Letter to Alice Austen from Annie Hedley 1885 November 9

Novbr [sic] 9th/85. Dear Alice, Will you join a few friends and take
lunch with Annie on Thursday next in a very informal manner. She would
like to have you and hopes you have no engagement. Lunch at one o’clock.
With love to your Grandmother, Mother and Aunt I am Your Friend Annie
Hedley, R.S.V.P. Clifton.

Letter to Alice Austen from Elisabeth B. Strong 1885 November 19

Piermont Nov. 19th/85 My dear Alice:-- I am ever so glad you can come
but shall suggest a slight change of plan, that is as regards the
“Calico-ball” itself. A day or two after I wrote you the date was
announced as the 11th, though the ball had previously been advertised to
come off on the 4th. You will certainly give me a visit of a week, will
you not? From Thursday until Monday is such a short time. About the
dresses; there will be all sorts I suppose, but the managers are anxious
the girls should war something bright and if the effect be old fashioned
so much the better. However if you would rather wear thin white do so.
[Satins or Satines, possibly misspelling of Sateens?], cambrics,
[silicias?, possibly misspelling for silesias] or anything of that sort
will answer. I have a red arrangement, part of a German peasant costume
or something of that sort. I shall probably wear that, and get a red and
white striped skirt to go with it if I can. I large white mull kerchief,
and a swiss cap trimmed with red ribbon complete the costume that I
shall probably wear. As you will see I am away from home; left New
Brunswick yesterday A.M., and expect to be here until next Tuesday or
Wednesday. Eva will spend Thanksgiving with us. This morning my cousin
and myself went out in the village cart, taking with us a young
gentleman for company and protection. This evening he is coming with his
cousin, sister and brother to play whist. By the way I have had my
fortune told, and I find that I am to meet my fate on the banks of the
Hudson. Now Piermont is situated on the Hudson, but that does not mean
necessarily that we are to meet here, does it? Saturday we expect to be
at my uncle’s at New Brighton for the day. I shall think of you as not
being so very far away. My dear, I have attained the advanced age of
twenty-one years, but I fail to see that people treat me with an
increase of respect. Can you not come about the time you had fixed even
though the “event” is postponed. Write again and let me know the day and
hour when I am to expect you. Yours with much love Elisabeth B. Strong

Letter to Alice Austen from Elisabeth B. Strong 1885 December 2

New Brunswick.

Dec. 2nd/’85

My dear Alice:

-- It will soon be only a week until the “Ball,” and after that the days
will fly away, particularly if I am not ready, and need more time;
otherwise seven days will seem an endless while. You may think me
slightly incoherent but the prospect of so much dancing, and with plenty
of room to spread yourself in is proving too much for my equilibrium.
Besides I have a mild headache this evening so am not quite responsible
for any vagaries you may find in this letter. My chief [missing word or
two ending in t] in writing you [one or two missing words] that if you
do [not?] want the bother [one or two missing words ending in-ting,
probably of getting] up a [costume for?] the occasion, white [will?] do
perfectly well. I have not spoken to many of the girls about dresses but
there will be some white ones worn I am sure. I have been hunting about
for material for a skirt, and have at last found something that will
answer, though it is not exactly what I was looking for. The next thing
is to make it up, and that part I do not enjoy much; still it will be as
plain as can be. Yes, I remember Miss Martin and her brother. On further
acquaintance what did you think of Mr. Baldwin? But you can answer that
question after you get here. I am getting impatient to see you, and am
looking every day for the letter which will tell me when to expect you.
By the way, are you fond of afternoon teas? There is to be one given by
the [Misses Janeway?] and Miss [missing name which] we will take [one or
two missing words] would like. It [one or two missing words] on the 12th
(Sat.) [Please remember?] me to [your?] mother and aunt and believe me
with much love for yourself Aff’ly yours Elisabeth B. Strong

Letter to Alice Austen from Elisabeth B. Strong 1885 December 8

New Brunswick

Dec. 8th/’85

My dear Alice:

I’ll just scratch you off a “few” lines to let you know that I fully
expect you to-morrow morning and will be at the station to meet you.
Shall get through with my French lesson just about in time to meet your
train. But my dear I cannot think of your going home on Saturday; you
surely can stay longer, and I am depending on you to go with me to Miss
Janeway’s “tea.” Mother does not go into society at all nor entertain
this winter otherwise I should give some sort of a company while you are
here. As it is I have asked no end of people to call, and you certainly
must give them a chance to do so. Thursday evening there is to be a
rehearsal of the play we are getting up, to which I shall take you
unless you have serious objections. We had our first rehearsal last
evening at the Hills’, and had great fun. The grand finale comes on the
1st of January at Mr. Hill’s. But my hands are stiff and writing is
attended with great difficulties. Tell your mother she must not expect
you on Saturday, and not until she sees you. With much love, farewell
until to-morrow. Aff’ly, Elisabeth.

Letter to Alice Austen from Julia Bredt 1885 December 8

Dec 13/85—

West Bethlehem

Dear Alice,

I always get mixed up when it comes to whose turn it is to write but I
think I wrote last and have never had an answer, am I not right? It
seems such a long time since I have seen or heard from you but I do hope
this letter will reach you and that you will answer very soon. I can not
think what to begin and tell you about as I am not sure what will
interest you I still go to school and do all the children last winter I
took private lessons, but this year the lady that taught me has started
a school & I go to it, do you go to school now? I do not think you do;
in your last letter you told me the Island was very quiet—is it in the
same state of repose now? Bethlehem is such a funny place for a week or
so it will be very very lively & then there will be nothing going on for
a great while Last Friday The Mustard & cheese club have a dramatic in
the [Lun?] Hotel it was splendid & the room crowded the name of the
Farce was “The silent protector.” Last year the same party gave one with
few additions. Then Saturday evening there was an entertainment in the
school hall given b the Moravian school the one to which [Trunie,
Trumie, Trinie or Trimie?], Fritz & Arthur Go. I did not go to it as
Fritz was not well & I stayed home, but Mama & all the rest went & they
said it was very good. I am very anxious for it to get cold so we will
have skating I enjoy it so very much & we generally have it pretty good.
I have never skated but on the canal & smaller creeks & ponds, but when
the River freezes every one says it is splendid. I am afraid it won’t do
that this year. The first or second day after Xmas I am going to be in
New York or Brooklyn, at least, that is, if nothing happens & I hope you
will be in New York & we can meet each other. Now Alice do answer this
soon & I will have to say good night, as I am so sleepy I don’t know
what to do lost [sic] of love from all & remember us all very kindly to
your Grandmama & keep lots for your self I am as ever Your
affectionately J.F. Bredt

UCT 8
230PM
TRANSIT

files.name: 1885_10-7-Oct 1003-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Party at Mrs. Wells' the same evening, and the Thursday evening following we all met again at a "Progressive Fly-ship" party at the Deshlers' O'Houres took no prize; it is against my principles to do such a thing. Our last party was a "door" or "hot" tea-party given by Mrs. Dr. Rick. It was very small only fourteen girls being invited but we had a very pleasant time.

I have been indulging in a very sort of work lately which could hardly

New Brunswick Oct. 7th '85

My dear Alice— I purposely waited until after your tennis tournament should be over before writing to you, hoping that you would afford me an opportunity for congratulating you on a glorious victory. I have been searching the paper each morning for news of you and was highly delighted when I saw you had beaten two of your opponents. But evidently hers was not what

files.name: 1885_10-7-Oct 1004-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content: time? Mr. Baldwin told me he went with your party, and was dancing with Miss Eccleston when she sprained her ankle. It must have somewhat spoiled the fun for all of you. I would have given a great deal to have stayed for the Ball; Cousin Erie urged me very much to do so and held out all sorts of inducements for a longer visit. If I had had a party-dress with me I don't believe I could have withstood the temptation. However we had a most delightful time at the phantom

files.name: 1885_10-7-Oct 1005-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
we plan York. Whenever I
write you, "yet other times are
"coming," and that we shall
settle one of these
things. Have you received a
very much shared
letter from Mrs. S.?
She
expressed a
great desire to see
and her eternal good
wishes to you.
Her first drive is 105
West 4th. Can't miss it.
I'll try to get your
picture if it is to your
light. Please let me
know you delivered
your message that the
Government has not
allowed you speech

I am waiting patiently for that picture of yourself you promised me. Does n't the proverb run "Patience waiters are so losers"? Let us hope it will be proved correct in this case. How is the Englishman who owns the camera or rather two cameras; does he come over three times a day as usual?

You should have been at church last Sunday evening; our choir rose in numbers to listen, and the behavior was what might have been

files.name: 1885_10-7-Oct 1006-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
expected. Without doubt Dr. Woodbridge is one of the most patient in existence.

I hope you will not form a very bad opinion of me for sending such a looking letter, but my ink and pen are both on a strike and I am too lazy to hunt up better. Please remember me to your mother and to Mrs. Miller also to Miss Wright when you see her. I have as yet had no time to settle my study or furniture but thought to do so "home-day." With much love to yourself and hoping soon to hear from you.

Be called "fancy-work," at any rate I do not fancy it! Isn't that most atrocious, but I beg any number of pardons and won't do so any more. The work referred to is housework and O, how I detest it! We have been without servants for more than a week and though we have a waitress coming (?) next Wednesday still we have as yet engaged no cook. New Brunswick is particularly destitute of that article of furniture just now, and can not get another to try

files.name: 1885_11-19-Nov 1001 copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Miss Alice Austen
Hapleton P.C.
Richmond Co.
Staten Island

files.name: 1885_11-19-Nov 1002-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Piermont
Nov. 19th/86

My dear Alice:

I am ever so glad you can come but shall suggest a slight change of plan, that is as regards the "calico-ball" itself. A day or two after I wrote you the date was announced as the 11th, though the ball had previously been advertised to come off on the 4th. You will certainly give me a visit of a week will you not? From Thursday until Monday is such a

my fate, on the banks of the Hudson. Nor Piermont is situated on the Hudson but that does not mean necessarily that we are to meet there, does it? Saturday we expect to be at my uncle's at Den Brighton for the day. I shall think of you as not being so very far away.

My dear, have attached the advanced age of twenty-one years, but I fail to see that people treat me with an increase of respect. Can you not come about the time you had fixed even though the "event" is postponed. Write again and let me know the day and hour when I am

files.name: 1885_11-19-Nov 1003-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
About the dresses: these will be all sorts of purpose, but the inauguration are antiques. The gable should bear something heightening in it if the effect is not better. However if you would have nothing to much the Zachary greasy fellow I will try to get by with one that is not well known.

I sent part of a German Pleasant Fortune or some thing of that sort. Shall probably be near that, and get a real and white tropical skirt to go with it if I can. A large white muffe pouch, and a small cap decorated with red ribbon complete the costume that I shall probably wear.

As you will see I am away from home: left New Brunswick yesterday 9 P.M. effect to be here until next Tuesday or Wednesday. Eva will spend Thanksgiving with us.

This morning my cousin and myself went out in the village cart, taking with us a young gentleman for company and protection. This evening he is coming with his cousin, sister and brother to play ghost.

By the way I have had my fortune told, and I find that I am to meet

files.name: 1885_11-2-Nov 4001 copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Miss Austin
Clifton
Staten Is.
NY

NEW YORK
NOV 2
530PM
85

files.name: 1885_11-2-Nov 4002-Bruce copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
5th Broadway
2 Nov 1885

Dear Miss Austin,

Our straw-ride of last Thursday has been turned into a dance at the boathouse for next Thursday - 5th inst. Please come and have a jolly time. Mrs Mac Donald and others will patronize the party. We will meet about eight o'clock.

Yours sincerely,
Ecm Bruce

files.name: 1885_11-3-Nov 3001 copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Miss Alice E. Austin
Stapleton P.C.
Staten Island
N.Y.

NEW YORK
NOV 10 30 AM
L 85

files.name: 1885_11-3-Nov 3002-Grace copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
but am getting better fast.
I am not going back to Brokies for the present, so may after Christmas but possibly not until next year. I want to try and get over my colds first. But I have my china painting and one can always find plenty to do here. What are you thinking of doing this winter? Though it is not much use to plan is it? Please let me hear from you soon, and let it be favorably, give my love to all the friends too as with much for yourself.

Sincerely yours,
Grace

2020 Fifth Ave N.Y.
Nov. 3rd 185

Dear Alice,

Don't we keep up a rushing correspondence, actually I am ashamed of you. Now I have had some excuse; doing a great deal of everything and not much time particular since I saw you last. But seriously when are you coming up. The weather

files.name: 1885_11-3-Nov 3003-Grace copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
will not be any pleasanter later, can't you come sometime next week, that will give you plenty of time to get ready.

Last week we were all busy at a fair for the benefit of our church. It was an extremely pretty one though I believe not financially successful. The ladies in charge of different tables chose the holidays in the year and dressed their tables to represent them. Christmas day was a lovely little cottage covered with snow (cotton) and greens. Washington's birthday a tent. April day an immense umbrella of white and pink mill and glass bead sewed on to keep for rain. May day a large may pole with the colored ribbons caught to different parts of the table. Thanksgiving day the prettiest of all, a thatched cottage with husked corn, pumpkins and fall gourds and flowers brought in as decorations.

I took a dreadful cold the last day and have not been out of the house since.

files.name: 1885_11-7-Nov 5001 copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Miss Alice Austin
Stapleton P.O.
Richmond Co.
Haten Island

files.name: 1885_11-7-Nov 5002 copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
NEW YORK
NOV 3
TR
LISN

files.name: 1885_11-7-Nov 5003-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
New Brunswick Nov. 7th '85

My dear Alice:

I've only been waiting to see what gaiety was in the wind before sending you this note. My father met with its revival the 4th of December and we are anticipating any amount of fun. It is not yet decided where it will be held, but probably in the "Assembly Rooms." Now my dear, I want to tell you that I expect a great treat.

Last Wednesday there was to be a Progressive party at Miss Bessie Palmer's. I do not think you met her last summer. Did you? The affair was so short at Dr. Scott's or his sister's, but I don't go because I didn't get an adequate invitation. It was a very pleasant affair.

But I must go on to more now. I am so stupid and slothful this morning; please excuse all deficiencies. I got a letter from Eva yesterday; has she

files.name: 1885_11-7-Nov 5004-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
you to say that you will come over and see me for Brunswick great treat. You will be able to visit as you can what day and hour to expect you will expect you will only let me know what day and hour to look of clothes allowable at the but something in the time Lancy wish me yourself and if I could get you want he called. These cases the poor may be stretched to believe almost everything that is not silk, velvet, b

wollen. Do not get up anything elaborate or you will outshine me. We certainly are going back to summer; the heat is really oppressive. I am hoping that it will clear off today so that we shall have a pleasant evening for the organ recital at the Second Reformed Church. Of course you have heard through your brother the news of the new organ here; I hope Prof. Clarence Eadby

files.name: 1885_11-9-Nov 2001 copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Miss Alice Austin,
Clifton,
Statue Island.

files.name: 1885_11-9-Nov 2002-Hedley copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Nov 19th/85

Dear Alice,

Will you join a few friends and take lunch with Annie on Thursday next in a very informal manner. She would like to have you

files.name: 1885_11-9-Nov 2003-Hedley copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
and hope you have no engagement. Lunch at one o'clock. With love to your grandmother, mother and aunt I am

Your friend,

Annie Kelly,
Clifton.

files.name: 1885_12-13-Dec 3001-bredt copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Miss A. Cuslan
Clifton
Richmond Co.
Staten Island

BETHLEHEM
DEC 20
8 PM
1885
PA.

POSTAGE

files.name: 1885_12-13-Dec 3002-Bredt copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
what to begin and tell you about, as I am not sure what will interest you. I still go to school every day. Last winter I took private lessons but this year the lady that taught me has started a school, so I go to it. Do you go to school now? I do not think you do.

In your last letter you told me the island was very quiet—is it in the same state of repose now? It is such a funny place for a week or so it will be very very lovely & then there will be nothing going on for a great while.

Last Friday the music & choral club gave a dramatic in the Sun Hotel, it was splendid & the room crowded. The name of the farce was "The silent protector." Last year the same party gave one

Dec. 13, 185—

Dear Alice,

I always get mixed up when it comes to whole letters it is too write—but I think I wrote last and have never face an answer am I not right? It seems such a long time since I have seen for heard from you but I do hope this letter will reach you and that you will answer soon. I can not think

files.name: 1885_12-13-Dec 3003-Bredt copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
with few addelions. Then Saturday evening there was an entertainment in the school hall given by the Moravian School, the one to which Thumir Fritz Arthur go. I did not go to it as Fritz was not well & I stayed home, but Mama & all the rest went & they said it was very good. I am very anxious for it to get cold so we will have skating. I enjoy it so very much & we generally have pretty good. I have never skated but on the canal & smaller creeks & ponds. But when the river freezes over our cap it is splendid. I am afraid it won't do that this year. The first or second day after Emma I am going to be in New York or Brooklyn at least, that is, if nothing happens & hope you will be in New York & we can meet each other. How Alice do answer this soon & I will have to say good night as I am so sleepy. I don't know what to do lost of love from all & remember us all very kindly to your Granddams & dear Fritz for yourself. I am as ever affectionately,
F. Wreat

files.name: 1885_12-2-Dec 2001-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Miss Alice Ann
Stapleton P.O.
Richmond Co.
Staten Island

files.name: 1885_12-2-Dec 2002-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
New Brunswick
Dec. 2nd '85

My dear Alice:-

It will soon be only a week until the "Ball," and after that the days will fly away, particularly if I am not ready and need more time; otherwise seven days will seem an endless while. You may think me slightly incoherent but the prospect of so much dancing, and with plenty of room to spread yourself in is growing too much for my equilibrium.

Every day for the letters which will tell me when to expect you. By the way, are you fond of afternoon teas? There is given by The runaway angel Miss Licht. I will take - would like it on the 12th Sat. Remember me to mother and aunt and believe me with much love for yourself

Affly yours
Elizabeth B. Strong

files.name: 1885_12-2-Dec 2003-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Besides I have a terrible headache this evening. I am not quite well, like for only a couple of days in this letter. My child is perfectly well. I have sent the brother into a hospital for a long time, and he has not spoken to Frank & the girls about it yet. There will be some more news soon, I am sure. I have been hunting about for material for a shirt, and have at last found something that will answer, though it is not exactly what I was looking for. The next thing is to make it up, and that I do not enjoy much; still it will be explained as can be.

Yes, I remember Miss Martin and her brother. On further acquaintance what did you think of Mr. Baldwin? But you can answer that question after you get here. I am getting impatient to see you, and am looking

files.name: 1885_12-8-Dec 1.1-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
New Brunswick.
Dec. 8th, '85

My dear Alice:

I'll just scratch you off the "few" lines to let you know that I fully expect you to-morrow morning and will be at the station to meet you. I shall get through with my French lesson just about in time to meet your train. But my dear I cannot think of your going home on

files.name: 1885_12-8-Dec 1.2-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content: Saturday; you surely can stay longer, and I am determined on you to go with me to Miss Jemmy's "tea". Mother does not go into society at all nor entertain otherwise this winter. I should give some sort of a company while you are here. As it is I have asked no end of people to call, and you certainly must give them a chance to do so. Thursday evening there is to be a rehearsal of the play, be any getting up, to which I shall

files.name: 1885_12-8-Dec 1.3-Strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
take you unless you have serious objections. We had our first rehearsal last evening at the Hill's, and had great fun. The grand finale comes on the 1st of January at Mr. Hill's. But my hands are stiff, and writing is attended with great difficulties. Tell your brother she must not expect you on Saturday, and not until she sees you.

With much love, farewell until to-morrow.

Aff'ly, Elizabeth.

files.name: 1885_12-8-Dec 1004-strong copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Miss Alice Austin
Stapleton P.O.
Richmond Co.
 Staten Island

files.name: 1885_4-25-April 1001 copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
18 Townsend Ave
Clifton 25th Apl '85

Dear Miss Austin,

Mr. Bruce & I are going to have a few friends on Wednesday next to spend the evening & would be very pleased to have the pleasure of your company.

Sincerely yours,
H.T. Langford

files.name: 1885_6-12-Alice Cornell Austen june 12001 copy.jpg.ref.json
files.content:
Friday, June 12th

My dearest Kate,

I was so glad to get the telegram. We are all right here, your grandmother is much better, eats real, and sees doctors come & uncle Dave and theaghe have been
